data.title: Diamondbacks vs. Dodgers: Fans look ahead after loss
data.meta_description: Wave your rally towel and follow the fan experience as the Diamondbacks square off vs. the\u00a0Los Angeles Dodgers in Game 1 of the\u00a0NLDS on Oct. 6, 2017.
data.text:
The Arizona Diamondbacks square off Friday night against the Los Angeles Dodgers in Game 1 of the National League Division Series. Wave your rally towel and follow the fan experience right here.

For a play-by-play of the game, visit our game-day blog. Score: D-Backs 5, Dodgers 9, final.

See you tomorrow

The Diamondbacks are down a game, but fans are ready to come back. Saturday's game starts at 6 p.m.

A final run

In the 9th, the D-Backs get a final run on a throwing error.

Final score: Dodgers 9, Diamondbacks 5.

Breathing room for Dodgers

Corey Seager triples to drive in a run, and Justin Turner singles to drive in another. Turner has five RBIs for the night.

Dodgers 9, Diamondbacks 4.

Watch out for snakes

As one man from Coolidge can tell you, rattlers bite back. (Or it's just a good read if you're tired of the game.)

Watch out, Dodgers. Maybe you should heed Victor Pratt's advice.

"Ain't gonna play with snakes no more," he said.

D-Backs strike back

Ketel Marte and Jeff Mathis hit back-to-back home runs in the top of the 7th inning against Clayton Kershaw. His night is done!

Dodgers 7, Diamondbacks 4.

Not over yet

J.D. Martinez slams a home run to left field as, finally, something goes right.

Dodgers 7, Diamondbacks 2.

There's always Game 2

D-Backs fans have been filing out of Alice Cooper'stown, apparently convinced that this isn't a deficit the team can come back from. By the end of the game, there might be nobody here.

Emotions were mixed online.

Some silver linings

As the Dodgers hits keep coming, azcentral sports columnist Dan Bickley finds some bright spots off the field.

On the field, another run comes across on a groundout by Yasiel Puig, giving him a second RBI.

Dodgers 7, Diamondbacks 1.

The good news: There are finally two outs.

Celebrity sightings

Celebrities abound at Dodger Stadium.

So far, we've heard of sightings of Tom Hanks, Rob Lowe, Omar Miller and beloved retired Dodgers sportscaster Vin Scully.

Oh, and Will Ferrell made it back to the big screen.

D-Backs have celebrity fans, too

Former "Malcolm in the Middle" star Frankie Muniz cheers on the D-Backs via Twitter.

Another one

Corey Seager's single in the bottom of the fourth scores Logan Forsythe, who had started the bottom of the fourth inning with a single.

Dodgers 5, Diamondbacks 1.

Then Justin Turner gets his fourth RBI of the night with another single. Dodgers 6, Diamondbacks 1.

Great play

Dodger first baseman Cody Bellinger makes a great play fielding a ground ball while going to his right, throwing out the Diamondbacks' Ketel Marte to close out the fourth inning.

New hope

Got one run back! AJ Pollock's homer in the third inning cuts the Diamondbacks' deficit to 3.

Fans at Alice Cooper'stown rose from their seats in applause after that first home run. The Diamondbacks are now on the board, and Pollock seems to have lit a fire in these people.

The cold shoulder

Fans are not happy going into the third inning. Down by four, the D-Backs aren't inspiring confidence from the people watching the game. At least one person watching at this bar said he didn't want to be interviewed about how he thought the Diamondbacks are playing tonight.

"I don't want to talk about it," the man said before turning and taking a long sip of his beer.

Lonely view

In a sea of blue, at least two Arizona Diamondbacks fans were spotted in the first inning. But they weren't looking too happy.

A small victory

It's not great, but it's the best news for the Diamondbacks all night.

Uniform review

Could it be the uniforms? Yasiel Puig doubles in another run, giving the Dodgers a 4-0 lead with nobody out in the first inning.

Cover your eyes ... and your ears

Dodgers fans got a chance to wave their rally towels early.

Justin Turner hits his third career post-season home run to put the Dodgers up, 3-0.

After first inning home run by Turner, the public-address announcer in Dodger Stadium tells the fans to chant, "Justin, Justin, Justin."

That seems to be a unique feature to that ballpark.

The Diamondbacks public-address announcer does not tell the crowd to yell Paul or JD or Jake.

Turn the channel

Head is spinning from all the channel changing at the start of the game.

If you went to grab a drink, they moved the game back to TBS and you're now watching Star Wars on TNT.

Waiting at the bar

A decent crowd of several dozen fans are waiting for the game at Alice Cooper'stown in downtown Phoenix. Everybody seems excited, using the Cubs game as a warmup for the main event.

Should be a good crowd once the game starts.

Cute D-Backs fans

These are some of our favorite fans!

Predictions?

So the Diamondbacks were 11-8 against the Dodgers this season. Any predictions on how this game will go?

Some experts had a few.

So far, the safest bet could be that the D-Backs game starts before the Yankees-Indians game ends. That game is 8-8 in the bottom of the 12th! (Update: Indians won in the 13th inning.)

Are you excited?

It's still a bit before the game, but it looks like fans are getting excited.

Getting ready

Before the game

Nickelodeon star Isabela Moner, known for her role in the show "100 Things to Do Before High School," is set to sing the national anthem ahead of the first pitch for the game.

We're sure she'll be great, but we're hoping to catch our Jesse McGuire giving a performance again soon when the teams return to Phoenix.

The first pitch will be thrown by 91-year-old former National League MVP Don Newcombe, who won the inaugural Cy Young Award in 1956.

Newcombe now serves as a special adviser to the Dodgers.

Here's your lineup

The lineup is set.

Diamondbacks pitcher Taijuan Walker (9-9, 3.49) will face Dodgers pitcher Clayton Kershaw (18-4, 2.31).

Check out the rest of the lineup here.

Not in L.A.? Catch the game here

Are you ready?

The first pitch is set for 7:31 p.m. Arizona time at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles.

Catch it on TV on TBS. The TV broadcast crew is Brian Anderson, Dennis Eckersley, Joe Simpson and Lauren Shehadi.

Find it on the radio on KMVP-AM (98.7) or KHOV-FM (105.1).

Or online via live streaming: MLB.tv will stream the NLDS and NLCS.
